text:
"Universal" drivers
have always been problematic regarding feature completeness. That's made
particularly painful with the specific printer was chosen over competing units
entirely because of a feature that is only available in a unit specific driver.
-- There are 10 kinds of people in the world... those who understand binary and
those who don't. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

metadata.topic: RE: A Practical Guide to PrintNightmare in 2024
metadata.subject: RE: [patchmanagement] RE: A Practical Guide to PrintNightmare in 2024
metadata.email_text_original:
[You don't often get email from melvin.backus@byers.com. Learn why this is
important at https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification ] "Universal" drivers
have always been problematic regarding feature completeness. That's made
particularly painful with the specific printer was chosen over competing units
entirely because of a feature that is only available in a unit specific driver.
-- There are 10 kinds of people in the world... those who understand binary and
those who don't. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ -----Original Message----- From:
patchmanagement@googlegroups.com On Behalf Of Hammer, Erich F Sent: Wednesday,
February 7, 2024 9:24 AM To: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com Subject: RE:
[patchmanagement] RE: A Practical Guide to PrintNightmare in 2024 I remember
needing to have three different versions of the HP "Universal" driver because
none of them supported the range of all the HP printers we had, and assigning
the "wrong" one would either print gibberish or disallow critical features for
some models. On Tuesday, February 6, 2024 at 18:27, Philip Elder eloquently
inscribed:
Link: None
